subsection.title: Quotients of Powers

li.p: We first write the numerator and denominator in factored form. Then we divide any common factors from the numerator and denominator. \dfrac{a^5}{a^3} = \dfrac{\cancel{a}\cdot \cancel{a}\cdot \cancel{a}\cdot a\cdot a}{\cancel{a}\cdot \cancel{a}\cdot \cancel{a}} = \dfrac{a^2}{1} = a^2 You may observe that the exponent of the quotient can be obtained by subtracting the exponent of the denominator from the exponent of the numerator. In other words, \dfrac{a^5}{a^3}= a^{5-3} = a^2

subsection.p: These examples suggest the following property.

assemblage.title: Second Law of Exponents
assemblage.p:
To divide two powers with the same base, we subtract the smaller exponent from the larger one, and keep the same base.
If the larger exponent occurs in the numerator, put the power in the numerator.
If the larger exponent occurs in the denominator, put the power in the denominator.

statement.p: In a quotient of powers, how do we know whether the new power appears in the numerator or the denominator?

answer.p: By which has the larger exponent

subsection.title: Quotients of Monomials
subsection.p: To divide one monomial by another, we apply the second law of exponents to the powers of each variable.

subsection.title: Greatest Common Factors
subsection.p: Now we consider several techniques for factoring polynomials. The first of these is factoring out the greatest common factor (GCF).

assemblage.title: Greatest Common Factor
assemblage.p: The greatest common factor (GCF) is the largest factor that divides evenly into each term of the polynomial: the largest numerical factor and the highest power of each variable.

statement.p: Find the greatest common factor for ~~4a^3b^2+6ab^3-18a^2b^4

solution.p: The largest integer that divides evenly into all three coefficients is 2. The highest power of a is a^1, and the highest power of b is b^2. Thus, the GCF is 2ab^2. Note that the exponent on each variable of 2ab^2 is the smallest exponent that appears on that variable among the terms of the polynomial.

statement.p: The exponent on each variable of the GCF is the exponent that appears on that variable among the terms of the polynomial.

subsection.p: Once we have found the greatest common factor for the polynomial, we can write each term as a product of the GCF and another factor. For example, the GCF of 8x^2-6x is 2x, and we can write 8x^2-6x = \blert{2x} \cdot 4x - \blert{2x} \cdot 3 We can then use the distributive law to write the expression on the right side as a product. \blert{2x} \cdot 4x - \blert{2x} \cdot 3 = \blert{2x} (4x-3) We say that we have factored out the greatest common factor from the polynomial.
For more complicated polynomials, we can divide the GCF into each term to find the remaining factors.

solution.p: The GCF for this polynomial is 2ab^2, as we saw in . We factor out the GCF from each term and write the polynomial as a product, 2ab^2(\hphantom{0000000000}) To find the factor inside parentheses, we divide each term of the polynomial by the GCF. \dfrac{4a^3b^2}{2ab^2}=\blert{2a^2},~~~~\dfrac{6ab^3}{2ab^2}=\blert{3b},~~~\dfrac{-18a^2b^4}{2ab^2}=\blert{-9ab^2} We apply the distributive law to factor 2ab^2 from each term. 4a^3b^2+6ab^3-18a^2b^4 \amp =2ab^2\cdot \blert{2a^2}+2ab^2 \cdot \blert{3b-}2ab^2 \cdot \blert{9ab^2} \amp = 2ab^2(2a^2+3b-9ab^2)

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: Sometimes the greatest common factor for a polynomial is not a monomial, but may instead have two or more terms.

solution.p: The given expression has two terms, and (2x+1) is a factor of each. We factor out the entire binomial (2x+1). x^2\blert{(2x+1)}-3\blert{(2x+1)} = \blert{(2x+1)} (x^2-3)

subsection.title: Factoring Quadratic Trinomials by Guess-and-Check
subsection.p: So far, we can factor quadratic trinomials of the form x^2+bx+c=0, where a=1. Recall that the factored form of x^2+bx+c=0 looks like (x+p)(x+q)~~~~~~ \text{where}~~~pq=c ~~~ \text{and} ~~~p+q=b
You may want to review the FOIL method discussed in Lesson.
What if the coefficient of a is not 1? Sometimes, if the coefficients are small, we can factor a quadratic expression by the guess-and-check method.

statement.p: Factor ~2x^2-7x+3~ into a product of two binomials.

solution.p: We begin by factoring the quadratic term, 2x^2, which can only be factored as x times 2x, so we can fill in the First terms in each binomial. 2x^2-7x+3 = (2x)(x) Next, we factor the constant term, 3, which can only be factored as 3 times 1. Because the linear term is negative, we make both factors negative: 3=-3(-1). Finally, we have to decide which number appears as the Last term in each binomial. We check O+I for each possibility. (2x-3)(x-1)~~~~O+I \amp = -2x-3x=-5x (2x-1)(x-3)~~~~\blert{O+I} \amp \blert{= -6x-x=-7x} The second choice gives the correct middle term, so the factorization is 2x^2-7x+3 = (2x-1)(x-3)

statement.p: When we factor a quadratic trinomial by the guess-and-check method, how do we check for the correct middle term?

subsection.p: Remember that you can always check your factorization by multiplying the factors together.

subsection.title: Quadratic Trinomials in Two Variables
subsection.p: So far, we have factored quadratic trinomials in one variable, that is, polynomials of the form ax^2+bx+c The method we learned can also be used to factor trinomials in two variables of the form ax^2+bxy+cy^2 In this expression, the first and last terms are quadratic terms, while the middle term is a cross-term consisting of the product of the two variables.

solution.p: As usual, we begin by factoring the first term into x times x. x^2+5xy+6y^2 = (x + )(x + ) Next we look for factors of the last term, 6y^2. In order to obtain the xy-term in the middle, we need a y in each factor. Thus the possibilities are y~~\text{and}~~6y~~~~~~~~\text{or}~~~~~~~~2y~~\text{and}~~3y We'll check the sum O+I for each possibility. (x+y)(x+6y)~~~~O+I \amp = 6xy+xy=7xy (x+2y)(x+3y)~~~~\blert{O+I} \amp \blert{= 3xy+2xy=5xy} The second possibility gives the correct middle term, so the factorization is x^2+5xy+6y^2 = (x+2y)(x+3y)

subsection.title: Combining Factoring Techniques
subsection.p: We should always begin factoring by checking to see if there is a common factor that can be factored out.

solution.p: We begin by factoring out the greatest common factor, 2b. 2b^3+8b^2+6b = 2b(b^2+4b+3) The remaining factor, b^2+4b+3, is a quadratic trinomial that can be factored. We look for two numbers p and q so that pq=3 and p+q=4. You can check that p=3 and q=1 will work.

statement.p: What should always be the first step in factoring a polynomial?

subsection.p: If the coefficients in a quadratic trinomial ax^2+bx+c are not prime numbers, the guess-and-check method may be time-consuming. In that case, we can use another technique that depends upon the following property of binomial products.

Now let's compute the product of the expressions along each diagonal of the rectangle: 3t^2 \cdot 6 = 18t^2~~~~~~\text{and}~~~~~~9t \cdot 2t = 18t^2 The two products are equal. This is not surprising when you think about it, because each diagonal product is the product of all four terms of the binomials, namely 3t,~2,~t, and 3, just multiplied in a different order. You can see where the diagonal entries came from in our example: 18t^2 \amp = 3t^2 \cdot 6 =3t \cdot t \cdot 2 \cdot 3 18t^2 \amp = 9t \cdot 2t =3t \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot t

subsection.p: Now we'll factor the trinomial 3x^2+10x+8 We'll try to reverse the steps for multiplication. Instead of starting with the factors on the outside of the rectangle, we begin by filling in the areas of the sub-rectangles.

sidebyside.p: \blert{\text{Step 1}~~} The quadratic term, goes in the upper left, and the constant term, 8, goes in the lower right, as shown in the figure.

subsection.p: What about the other two entries? We know that their sum must be 10x, but we don't know what expressions go in each! This is where we use our observation that the products on the two diagonals are equal.

\blert{\text{Step 2}~~} We compute the product of the entries on the first diagonal: D=3x^2 \cdot 8 = 24x^2 The product of the entries on the other diagonal must also be 24x^2. We now know two things about those entries: \amp \text {1. Their product is}~~24x^2~~\text{and} \amp \text {2. Their sum is}~~10x
\blert{\text{Step 3}~~} To find the two unknown entries, we list all the ways to factor D=24x^2, then choose the factors whose sum is 10x.

sidebyside.p: \blert{\text{Step 4}~~} We see that the last pair of factors, 4x and 6x, has a sum of 10x. We enter these factors in the remaining sub-rectangles. (It doesn't matter which one goes in which spot.) We now have all the sub-rectangles filled in, as shown at right.

subsection.p: Finally, we work backwards to discover what length and width produce the areas of the four subrectangles.

\blert{\text{Step 5}~~} We factor each row of the rectangle, and write the factors on the outside. Start with the top row, factoring out x and writing the result, 3x+4, at the top, as shown at right. We get the same result when we factor 2 from the bottom row.

sidebyside.p: The final rectangle is shown at right, and the factors of 3x^2+10x+8 appear as the length and width of the rectangle. Our factorization is thus 3x^2+10x+8=(x+2)(3x+4)

assemblage.title: To Factor ~ax^2+bx+c~ Using the Box Method

ol.li: Write the quadratic term ax^2 in the upper left sub-rectangle, and the constant term c in the lower right.
Multiply these two terms to find the diagonal product, D.
List all possible factors px and qx of D, and choose the pair whose sum is the linear term, bx, of the quadratic trinomial.
Write the factors px and qx in the remaining sub-rectangles.
Factor each row of the rectangle, writing the factors on the outside. These are the factors of the quadratic trinomial.
